awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Relational Cultures, Inequality and Belonging: Race, Class and Teacher-Student Relationships in Two U.S. High Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
Research identifies minority students’ relationships with teachers as one driver of racial achievement gaps in American schools. Students with strong teacher relationships perform better academically. However, minority students experience more negative and less caring relationships with teachers than majority peers. This project addresses the social processes producing these racial disparities in teacher-student relationships. A growing body of research suggests the race and class composition of schools plays a role: schools with more majority and higher SES students have stronger teacher-student relationships overall but also wider achievement gaps between majority and minority students while schools with more minority and lower SES students have weaker relationships overall but also less disparity. Current approaches cannot explain 1) how predominantly minority and majority schools differ in developing teacher-student relationships overall and 2) how majority and minority students’ relationships with teachers vary within these differing environments. This project addresses these crucial factors through a comparative ethnography of a predominantly majority high school and a predominantly minority high school. This study will expand knowledge of inequality by showing how relationships are formed, maintained, and given meaning in school environments with varying outcomes for majority and minority students. The project will inform the design and implementation of educational reforms through identifying specific school-and classroom-level mechanisms that either support or constrain the development of teacher-student relationships. While focusing on relational cultures and inequality in schools, this project also has implications for youth-adult relationships in other organizational settings, such as in the criminal justice system and the workplace, thus implicating policies in these settings, as well. 


This project argues that schools have a relational culture, encompassing shared expectations and practices shaping interactions between teachers and students. The project analyzes how seemingly equivalent relationships between teachers and students can take varying forms in different schools with important implications for student outcomes. Through comparing across schools, this project analyzes: 1) how relational cultures are racialized and differentiated by social class, 2) how relational cultures produce differences in majority and minority students’ relationships with teachers, and 3) how students' relationships with teachers impact their school experience and outcomes. To address these questions, this project utilizes eight months of daily observations and in-depth interviews with teachers (N=40), students (N=96), and administrators (N=20) at one majority white high school and one majority-minority high school. Data are analyzed using Atlas.TI to derive coding and themes capturing the similarities and differences across and within the cases.  Findings from the project will inform sociological theories regarding relational cultures, inequality regimes, and organizational processes, particularly for organizations varying in majority-minority concentration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This dissertation sought to address four main research questions through a comparative ethnography of two high schools: 1) how relational cultures are racialized and classed, 2) how (racialized and classed) relational cultures produce differences in white, Black and Latinx students’ relationships with teachers, and 3) how student’s relationships with teachers impact their school experience and outcomes. Relational cultures are an informal but consequential backdrop that shapes the distribution of relationships among teachers and students. Specifically, relational cultures consist of shared priorities, emotional ideals and practices shaping interactions between teachers and students. To address these research questions, two main forms of data collection were conducted during the funding period. First, the co-PI conducted approximately 800 hours of in-school and online observations during classes and other school activities. Second, 37 interviews were conducted with students and 23 interviews with teachers. Due to the COVID19 pandemic, these interviews were conducted online using Zoom rather than in-person. Utilizing this data, the following outcomes have been achieved.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes

My data has produced results with regards to the research questions that will make a significant intellectual contribution to the discipline of sociology. Two in-progress articles will share these results with the discipline. The first article introduces relational cultures as a new theoretical approach to studying inequality that shows how relationships are formed, maintained and given meaning within institutional environments. While focusing on relational cultures and inequality in schools, this article will speak to the implications of the relational cultures approach for research on youth-adult relationships in other organizational settings, such as the criminal justice system, and for relationships in the workplace. The second article utilizes data from this project’s funding period to show how diverging organizational responses to the Covid19 pandemic, influenced by pre-existing school cultures, shaped whether inequalities among students were challenged or deepened during virtual schooling. This paper will help sociologists and education scholars better understand the ongoing consequences of the Covid19 pandemic on educational outcomes.

Broader Impact Outcomes

This project has already begun to contribute to ongoing efforts by school officials to improve teacher-student relationships. First, as part of the project partnership with the two school districts in this study, findings were shared with school officials throughout data collection. During summer 2020, a brief report was shared that used data to demonstrate that stronger teacher-student relationships lead to higher student engagement in virtual schooling and to identify specific practices teachers can use to strengthen relationships online. During winter 2021 a second set of data was shared regarding student engagement and use of time during virtual schooling. Lastly, during fall 2022, a more comprehensive report about the state of teacher-student relationships at both schools will be shared with the districts. This report will also identify ways that each district can better support these relationships.
